questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question:
With respect to simple linear regression, a residual is best described as the difference between the observed value of a dependent variable and:

  1. its mean.
  2. its estimated value using a fitted regression line based on the sample.
  3. its expected value based on the true underlying population relationship.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because we look at the sum of squared deviations of the observations from the mean to capture [the variation of the dependent variable]. Our goal is to understand what explains the variation of Y. The variation of Y is often referred to as the sum of squares total (SST), or the total sum of squares. Therefore, the difference between an observation and the mean of the dependent variable is not the observation's residual. Correct because the residual for the i th observation, e i , is how much the observed value of Y i differs from the estimated [value] using the regression line. Further, the residual refers to the fitted linear relation based on the sample. Incorrect because the error term refers to the true underlying population relationship, whereas the residual refers to the fitted linear relation based on the sample. Further, the error term, or simply the error, represents the difference between the observed value of Y and that expected from the true underlying population relation between Y and X . Simple Linear Regression describe a simple linear regression model, how the least squares criterion is used to estimate regression coefficients, and the interpretation of these coefficients
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because we look at the sum of squared deviations of the observations from the mean to capture [the variation of the dependent variable]. Our goal is to understand what explains the variation of Y. The variation of Y is often referred to as the sum of squares total (SST), or the total sum of squares. Therefore, the difference between an observation and the mean of the dependent variable is not the observation's residual.

  2. Correct because the residual for the ith observation, ei, is how much the observed value of Yi differs from the estimated [value] using the regression line. Further, the residual refers to the fitted linear relation based on the sample.

  3. Incorrect because the error term refers to the true underlying population relationship, whereas the residual refers to the fitted linear relation based on the sample. Further, the error term, or simply the error, represents the difference between the observed value of Y and that expected from the true underlying population relation between Y and X.

Simple Linear Regression

  • describe a simple linear regression model, how the least squares criterion is used to estimate regression coefficients, and the interpretation of these coefficients

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: The predicted value of the companyâ€™s ROE if its GO is 10 percent is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The predicted value of ROE = 4 + (1.8 Ã— 10) = 22.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The predicted value of ROE = 4 + (1.8 Ã— 10) = 22.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: The change in ROE for a change in GO from 5 percent to 6 percent is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The slope coefficient of 1.8 is the expected change in the dependent variable ( ROE ) for a one-unit change in the independent variable ( GO ).
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The slope coefficient of 1.8 is the expected change in the dependent variable (ROE) for a one-unit change in the independent variable (GO).

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: The residual in the case of a GO of 8 percent and an observed ROE of 21 percent is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The predicted value is ROE = 4 + (1.8 Ã— 8) = 18.4. The observed value of ROE is 21, so the residual is 2.6 = 21.0 âˆ’ 18.4.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The predicted value is ROE = 4 + (1.8 Ã— 8) = 18.4. The observed value of ROE is 21, so the residual is 2.6 = 21.0 âˆ’ 18.4.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Homoskedasticity is best described as the situation in which the variance of the residuals of a regression is:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Homoskedasticity is the situation in which the variance of the residuals is constant across the observations.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Homoskedasticity is the situation in which the variance of the residuals is constant across the observations.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: The variable SHIFT is best described as:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. SHIFT is an indicator or dummy variable because it takes on only the values 0 and 1.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. SHIFT is an indicator or dummy variable because it takes on only the values 0 and 1.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: The interpretation of the intercept is the mean of the annual growth rate of the money supply:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. In a simple regression with a single indicator variable, the intercept is the mean of the dependent variable when the indicator variable takes on a value of zero, which is before the shift in policy in this case.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. In a simple regression with a single indicator variable, the intercept is the mean of the dependent variable when the indicator variable takes on a value of zero, which is before the shift in policy in this case.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: The interpretation of the slope is the:

choices.A: change in the annual growth rate of the money supply per year.
choices.B: average annual growth rate of the money supply after the shift in policy.
choices.C: difference in the average annual growth rate of the money supply from before to after the shift in policy.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Whereas the intercept is the average of the dependent variable when the indicator variable is zero (i.e., before the shift in policy), the slope is the difference in the mean of the dependent variable from before to after the change in policy.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Whereas the intercept is the average of the dependent variable when the indicator variable is zero (i.e., before the shift in policy), the slope is the difference in the mean of the dependent variable from before to after the change in policy.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Testing whether there is a change in the money supply growth after the shift in policy, using a 0.05 level of significance, we conclude that there is:

choices.A: sufficient evidence that the money supply growth changed.
choices.B: not enough evidence that the money supply growth is different from zero.
choices.C: not enough evidence to indicate that the money supply growth changed.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The null hypothesis of no difference in the annual growth rate is rejected at the 0.05 level: The calculated test statistic of âˆ’8.16188 is outside the bounds of Â±2.048.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The null hypothesis of no difference in the annual growth rate is rejected at the 0.05 level: The calculated test statistic of âˆ’8.16188 is outside the bounds of Â±2.048.

questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The coefficient of determination is the same as R2, which is 0.7436 in the table.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: If the ratio of net income to sales for a restaurant is 5 percent, the predicted ratio of cash flow from operations (CFO) to sales is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. To make a prediction using the regression model, multiply the slope coefficient by the forecast of the independent variable and add the result to the intercept. Expected value of CFO to sales = 0.077 + (0.826 Ã— 5) = 4.207.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. To make a prediction using the regression model, multiply the slope coefficient by the forecast of the independent variable and add the result to the intercept. Expected value of CFO to sales = 0.077 + (0.826 Ã— 5) = 4.207.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Is the relationship between the ratio of cash flow to operations and the ratio of net income to sales significant at the 0.05 level?

choices.A: No, because the R 2 is greater than 0.05
choices.B: No, because the p -values of the intercept and slope are less than 0.05
choices.C: Yes, because the p -values for F and t for the slope coefficient are less than 0.05

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The p -value is the smallest level of significance at which the null hypotheses concerning the slope coefficient can be rejected. In this case, the p -value is less than 0.05, and thus the regression of the ratio of cash flow from operations to sales on the ratio of net income to sales is significant at the 5 percent level.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The p-value is the smallest level of significance at which the null hypotheses concerning the slope coefficient can be rejected. In this case, the p-value is less than 0.05, and thus the regression of the ratio of cash flow from operations to sales on the ratio of net income to sales is significant at the 5 percent level.

Solution

C is correct. From the regression equation, Expected return = 0.0138 + (âˆ’0.6486 Ã— âˆ’0.01) = 0.0138 + 0.006486 = 0.0203, or 2.03 percent.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression

choices.A: Stellarâ€™s returns explain 2.11 percent of the variability in CPIENG.
choices.B: Stellarâ€™s returns explain 14.52 percent of the variability in CPIENG.
choices.C: changes in CPIENG explain 2.11 percent of the variability in Stellarâ€™s returns.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. R 2 is the coefficient of determination. In this case, it shows that 2.11% of the variability in Stellarâ€™s returns is explained by changes in CPIENG.

Solution

C is correct. R2 is the coefficient of determination. In this case, it shows that 2.11% of the variability in Stellarâ€™s returns is explained by changes in CPIENG.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: For the analysis run by Batten, which of the following is an incorrect conclusion from the regression output?

choices.A: The estimated intercept from Battenâ€™s regression is statistically different from zero at the 0.05 level of significance.
choices.B: In the month after the CPIENG declines, Stellarâ€™s common stock is expected to exhibit a positive return.
choices.C: Viewed in combination, the slope and intercept coefficients from Battenâ€™s regression are not statistically different from zero at the 0.05 level of significance.

questions.explanation: Solution C is the correct response because it is a false statement. The slope and intercept are both statistically different from zero at the 0.05 level of significance.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is the correct response because it is a false statement. The slope and intercept are both statistically different from zero at the 0.05 level of significance.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Based on Exhibit 2, the number of degrees of freedom for the t-test of the slope coefficient in this regression is:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The degrees of freedom are the number of observations minus the number of parameters estimated, which equals 2 in this case (the intercept and the slope coefficient). The number of degrees of freedom is 50 âˆ’ 2 = 48.

Solution

A is correct. The degrees of freedom are the number of observations minus the number of parameters estimated, which equals 2 in this case (the intercept and the slope coefficient). The number of degrees of freedom is 50 âˆ’ 2 = 48.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Which of the following should Liu conclude from the results shown in Exhibit 2?

choices.A: The average short interest ratio is 5.4975.
choices.B: The estimated slope coefficient is different from zero at the 0.05 level of significance.
choices.C: The debt ratio explains 30.54 percent of the variation in the short interest ratio.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The t -statistic is âˆ’2.2219, which is outside the bounds created by the critical t -values of Â±2.011 for a two-tailed test with a 5 percent significance level. The value of 2.011 is the critical t -value for the 5 percent level of significance (2.5 percent in one tail) for 48 degrees of freedom. A is incorrect because the mean of the short interest ratio is 192.3 Ã· 50 = 3.846. C is incorrect because the debt ratio explains 9.33 percent of the variation of the short interest ratio.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The t-statistic is âˆ’2.2219, which is outside the bounds created by the critical t-values of Â±2.011 for a two-tailed test with a 5 percent significance level. The value of 2.011 is the critical t-value for the 5 percent level of significance (2.5 percent in one tail) for 48 degrees of freedom. A is incorrect because the mean of the short interest ratio is 192.3 Ã· 50 = 3.846. C is incorrect because the debt ratio explains 9.33 percent of the variation of the short interest ratio.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Based on Exhibit 1, Olabudo should:

choices.A: conclude that the inflation predictions are unbiased.
choices.B: reject the null hypothesis that the slope coefficient equals one.
choices.C: reject the null hypothesis that the intercept coefficient equals zero.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. We fail to reject the null hypothesis of a slope equal to one, and we fail to reject the null hypothesis of an intercept equal to zero. The test of the slope equal to 1.0 is ğ‘¡ = 0.9830 âˆ’ 1.000 0.0155 = âˆ’ 1.09677 t = 0.9830 âˆ’ 1.000 0.0155 = âˆ’ 1.09677 . The test of the intercept equal to 0.0 is ğ‘¡ = 0.0001 âˆ’ 0.0000 .00002 = 0.5000 t = 0.0001 âˆ’ 0.0000 .00002 = 0.5000 . Therefore, we conclude that the forecasts are unbiased.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. We fail to reject the null hypothesis of a slope equal to one, and we fail to reject the null hypothesis of an intercept equal to zero. The test of the slope equal to 1.0 is

ğ‘¡=0.9830âˆ’1.0000.0155=âˆ’1.09677t=0.9830âˆ’1.0000.0155=âˆ’1.09677.

The test of the intercept equal to 0.0 is

ğ‘¡=0.0001âˆ’0.0000.00002=0.5000t=0.0001âˆ’0.0000.00002=0.5000.

Therefore, we conclude that the forecasts are unbiased.

Make the prediction given the US CPI forecast of 2.8: ğ‘Œ âŒ¢ = ğ‘ 0 Ë† + ğ‘ 1 Ë† ğ‘‹ = 0.0001 + ( 0.9830 Ã— 2.8 ) = 2.7525. Y âŒ¢ = b 0 ^ + b 1 ^ X = 0.0001 + 0.9830 Ã— 2.8 = 2.7525. . Step 2. Step 3. Compute the prediction interval: ğ‘Œ Ë† Â± ğ‘¡ ğ‘ Ã— ğ‘  ğ‘“ Y ^ Â± t c Ã— s f . 2.7525 Â± (2.0 Ã— 0.0009) Lower bound: 2.7525 âˆ’ (2.0 Ã— 0.0009) = 2.7506. Upper bound: 2.7525 + (2.0 Ã— 0.0009) = 2.7544. Given the US CPI forecast of 2.8, the 95 percent prediction interval is 2.7506 to 2.7544.

Solution

A is correct. The forecast interval for inflation is calculated in three steps:

Step 1. Make the prediction given the US CPI forecast of 2.8:

ğ‘ŒâŒ¢=ğ‘0Ë†+ğ‘1Ë†ğ‘‹=0.0001+(0.9830Ã—2.8)=2.7525.YâŒ¢=b0^+b1^X=0.0001+0.9830Ã—2.8=2.7525..

Step 2. Compute the variance of the prediction error:

ğ‘ 2ğ‘“=ğ‘ 2ğ‘’{1+(1/ğ‘›)+[(ğ‘‹ğ‘“âˆ’ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯)2]/[(ğ‘›âˆ’1)Ã—ğ‘ 2ğ‘¥]}.ğ‘ 2ğ‘“=0.00092{1+(1/60)+[(2.8âˆ’1.3350)2]/[(60âˆ’1)Ã—0.75392]}.ğ‘ 2ğ‘“=0.00000088.ğ‘ ğ‘“=0.0009.sf2=se21+1/n+Xfâˆ’XÂ¯2/nâˆ’1Ã—sx2.sf2=0.000921+1/60+2.8âˆ’1.33502/60âˆ’1Ã—0.75392.sf2=0.00000088.sf=0.0009.

Step 3. Compute the prediction interval:

ğ‘ŒË†Â±ğ‘¡ğ‘Ã—ğ‘ ğ‘“Y^Â±tcÃ—sf.2.7525 Â± (2.0 Ã— 0.0009)Lower bound: 2.7525 âˆ’ (2.0 Ã— 0.0009) = 2.7506.Upper bound: 2.7525 + (2.0 Ã— 0.0009) = 2.7544.

Given the US CPI forecast of 2.8, the 95 percent prediction interval is 2.7506 to 2.7544.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Which of Olabudoâ€™s observations of forecasting is correct?
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The confidence level influences the width of the forecast interval through the critical t -value that is used to calculate the distance from the forecasted value: The larger the confidence level, the wider the interval. Therefore, Observation 1 is not correct. Observation 2 is correct. The greater the standard error of the estimate, the greater the standard error of the forecast.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The confidence level influences the width of the forecast interval through the critical t-value that is used to calculate the distance from the forecasted value: The larger the confidence level, the wider the interval. Therefore, Observation 1 is not correct.

Observation 2 is correct. The greater the standard error of the estimate, the greater the standard error of the forecast.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Which of Vasilevaâ€™s assumptions regarding regression analysis is incorrect?
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The assumptions of the linear regression model are that (1) the relationship between the dependent variable and the independent variable is linear in the parameters b 0 and b 1 , (2) the residuals are independent of one another, (3) the variance of the error term is the same for all observations, and (4) the error term is normally distributed. Assumption 3 is incorrect because the dependent variable need not be normally distributed.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The assumptions of the linear regression model are that (1) the relationship between the dependent variable and the independent variable is linear in the parameters b0 and b1, (2) the residuals are independent of one another, (3) the variance of the error term is the same for all observations, and (4) the error term is normally distributed. Assumption 3 is incorrect because the dependent variable need not be normally distributed.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression

choices.B: the intercept is less than or equal to zero.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Crude oil returns explain the Amtex share returns if the slope coefficient is statistically different from zero. B is incorrect because the calculated t -statistic is ğ‘¡ = 0.0095 âˆ’ 0.0000 0.0078 = 1.2179 t = 0.0095 âˆ’ 0.0000 0.0078 = 1.2179 , which is less than the critical value of +2.441.

which is outside the bounds of the critical values of Â±2.728.

B is incorrect because the calculated t-statistic is ğ‘¡=0.0095âˆ’0.00000.0078=1.2179t=0.0095âˆ’0.00000.0078=1.2179, which is less than the critical value of +2.441.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: Using information from Exhibit 2, the 99 percent prediction interval for Amtex share return for Month 37 is best described as:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The predicted share return is 0.0095 + [0.2354 Ã— (âˆ’0.01)] = 0.0071. The lower limit for the prediction interval is 0.0071 âˆ’ (2.728 Ã— 0.0469) = âˆ’0.1208, and the upper limit for the prediction interval is 0.0071 + (2.728 Ã— 0.0469) = 0.1350. A is incorrect because the bounds of the interval should be based on the standard error of the forecast and the critical t -value, not on the mean of the dependent variable. B is incorrect because bounds of the interval are based on the product of the standard error of the forecast and the critical t -value, not simply the standard error of the forecast.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The predicted share return is 0.0095 + [0.2354 Ã— (âˆ’0.01)] = 0.0071. The lower limit for the prediction interval is 0.0071 âˆ’ (2.728 Ã— 0.0469) = âˆ’0.1208, and the upper limit for the prediction interval is 0.0071 + (2.728 Ã— 0.0469) = 0.1350.

A is incorrect because the bounds of the interval should be based on the standard error of the forecast and the critical t-value, not on the mean of the dependent variable.

B is incorrect because bounds of the interval are based on the product of the standard error of the forecast and the critical t-value, not simply the standard error of the forecast.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: At a 0.01 level of significance, Jones should conclude that:

choices.A: the mean net profit margin is 0.5987 percent.
choices.B: the variation of the fixed asset turnover explains the variation of the natural log of the net profit margin.
choices.C: a change in the fixed asset turnover from three to four times is likely to result in a change in the net profit margin of 0.5987 percent.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The p -value corresponding to the slope is less than 0.01, so we reject the null hypothesis of a zero slope, concluding that the fixed asset turnover explains the natural log of the net profit margin.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The p-value corresponding to the slope is less than 0.01, so we reject the null hypothesis of a zero slope, concluding that the fixed asset turnover explains the natural log of the net profit margin.

questions.title: Simple Linear Regression
questions.question: The predicted net profit margin for a company with a fixed asset turnover of 2 times is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The predicted natural log of the net profit margin is 0.5987 + (2 Ã— 0.2951) = 1.1889. The predicted net profit margin is ğ‘’ 1.1889 = 3.2835 e 1.1889 = 3.2835 %.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The predicted natural log of the net profit margin is 0.5987 + (2 Ã— 0.2951) = 1.1889. The predicted net profit margin is ğ‘’1.1889=3.2835e1.1889=3.2835%.
